@pavel-shirshov the PR is now broken into 6 commits. As per offline discussion, the rendering result depends on the Python and so our rendered templates differ since it relies on the order of the output. This is a template issue and is not a cfggen issue.

reviews.body:
As comments.
My opinion: This PR should be split into many. Currently it is hard to check some sonic-cfggen results because you moved the files from one place to another and the history was lost.
Also the order has been changed, it is very hard to check that nothing was broken with this change.
I'd suggest:
1. Remove natsorted and review changes
2. Add Py2+Py3 code. The code will be changed, but target files must be unchanged
3. Move Py2 target files to its own directory and add Py3 target files (why d0 we need two different set of target files at first?)
4. Make the tests better (I'd introduce pytest here)

@bingwang-ms: Thanks for the fix! FYI, this is not applicable to the 201811 branch, as procdockerstatsd does not exist in that branch.

> @bingwang-ms: Thanks for the fix! FYI, this is not applicable to the 201811 branch, as procdockerstatsd does not exist in that branch.

Got it. Thanks.
@vboykox: Thanks for opening this PR! Is it ready for merge? I saw "WIP" in the title, so I wanted to wait for an update from you.
@jleveque yes, the PR is ready for merge

@vboykox: The Python 3 sonic-platform-common package will also need to be installed in the [PMon container](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/rules/docker-platform-monitor.mk). Do you intend to do this in a separate PR?

> @vboykox: The Python 3 sonic-platform-common package will also need to be installed in the [PMon container](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/rules/docker-platform-monitor.mk). Do you intend to do this in a separate PR?

Thanks for pointing that out

@vboykox: The Docker container install of the Python 3 wheel is failing. The issue is it's trying to install a Python 3 wheel using Python 2 pip. This is because the Dockerfile is using a macro from dockers/dockerfile-macros.j2, but the macro needs to be updated to be smarter. In the meantime, I suggest you update [this section](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/dockers/docker-platform-monitor/Dockerfile.j2#L44-L46) to work like the change I made [here](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/platform/vs/docker-sonic-vs/Dockerfile.j2#L106-L111).

I can work on updating the macro in the future.
@tahmed-dev  Do we need this change in 201811 as well?

> @tahmed-dev Do we need this change in 201811 as well?

@yxieca No we don't. [PR:4599](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/4599) is only in 201911 and 202006

@abdosi @lguohan  When bgpmon fail to run it has no impact to the BGP functionality.  The only impact it will have is to other potential components that consume the state DB that bgpmon produces.  So it depends on the definition of what constitute to be a critical process for the BGP docker.  If all agree I can certainly add it to be part of the critical processes.

> @abdosi @lguohan When bgpmon fail to run it has no impact to the BGP functionality. The only impact it will have is to other potential components that consume the state DB that bgpmon produces. So it depends on the definition of what constitute to be a critical process for the BGP docker. If all agree I can certainly add it to be part of the critical processes.

@gechiang In my opinion this is critical process as SNMP will use it for polling Device BGP health.
i am thinking it is not critical, we can do autorestart in the supervisord configuration, but not restart bgp process.

> i am thinking it is not critical, we can do autorestart in the supervisord configuration, but not restart bgp process.

ok,  that is better than container auto-restart.  Supervisor auto-restart should be good for this process
@lguohan @abdosi Thanks for the comment.  I will work on another PR to make this change on master branch and hopefully cherry-pick-able for 201911 branch.
@gechiang, should this PR be closed or stay? Thanks.
@lguohan Could you please review and merge

> lgtm. May I know how we came up with `/80` prefix?

this one mention about this https://medium.com/@skleeschulte/how-to-enable-ipv6-for-docker-containers-on-ubuntu-18-04-c68394a219a2

However i can-not find on official Docker documentation. May be this Docker limitation has been removed.  


=======

The subnet for Docker containers should at least have a size of /80, so that an IPv6 address can end with the container’s MAC address and you prevent NDP neighbor cache invalidation issues in the Docker layer.
=======

latestReviews.body: lgtm. May I know how we came up with `/80` prefix?

@abdosi Can you please cherry-pick this to 201911?

@abdosi, @jleveque : I am wondering if the change should be done in the `hostcfgd`. Another approach is to template the change into `init_cfg.json.j2` and move the template rendering out of `sonic_debian_extension.j2` ro `rc.local` under `FIRST_BOOT_FILE` flag there. the reason is to keep hostcfg as simple and multi-asic agnostic.

> the reason is to keep hostcfg as simple and multi-asic agnostic.

I agree with this sentiment. I can't think of a reason we need to build init_cfg.json into the image. We could generate it on first boot.

> > the reason is to keep hostcfg as simple and multi-asic agnostic.
> 
> I agree with this sentiment. I can't think of a reason we need to build init_cfg.json into the image. We could generate it on first boot.

Thanks @tahmed-dev for the quick discussion. @jleveque  generating init_cfg.json during boot time is not possible as it depends on some compile time variable.  Also to make hostcfgd agnostic of multi-asic we will need to update Feature table to have service instance count for each feature for which we have to read again generated_service_conf file during first boot and can't be just template based.
@abdosi: Good points. I guess it isn't as easy to move the init_cfg.json generation to first boot as I hoped.
@jleveque and @tahmed-dev can you please help review this.

> > > the reason is to keep hostcfg as simple and multi-asic agnostic.
> > 
> > 
> > I agree with this sentiment. I can't think of a reason we need to build init_cfg.json into the image. We could generate it on first boot.
> 
> Thanks @tahmed-dev for the quick discussion. @jleveque generating init_cfg.json during boot time is not possible as it depends on some compile time variable. Also to make hostcfgd agnostic of multi-asic we will need to update Feature table to have service instance count for each feature for which we have to read again generated_service_conf file during first boot and can't be just template based.

@abdosi what about extending information about services in the init_cfg.json regarding the where the feature should run host/per namespace/both. The hostcfgd can then check the multi_npu flag and act accordingly.

> > > > the reason is to keep hostcfg as simple and multi-asic agnostic.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I agree with this sentiment. I can't think of a reason we need to build init_cfg.json into the image. We could generate it on first boot.
> > 
> > 
> > Thanks @tahmed-dev for the quick discussion. @jleveque generating init_cfg.json during boot time is not possible as it depends on some compile time variable. Also to make hostcfgd agnostic of multi-asic we will need to update Feature table to have service instance count for each feature for which we have to read again generated_service_conf file during first boot and can't be just template based.
> 
> @abdosi what about extending information about services in the init_cfg.json regarding the where the feature should run host/per namespace/both. The hostcfgd can then check the multi_npu flag and act accordingly.

@tahmed-dev Updated accordingly.

comments.body:
Added one more change to include Monit to monitor this new daemon under BGP so that when it failed/crashed, it will raise an alert to syslog the issue.  It will show up something like following:

```
Sep 10 03:36:24.532960 str-s6000-acs-8 ERR monit[21086]: 'bgpmon' process is not running
Sep 10 03:37:24.615276 str-s6000-acs-8 ERR monit[21086]: 'sflowmgrd' process is not running
Sep 10 03:37:24.661284 str-s6000-acs-8 ERR monit[21086]: 'bgpmon' process is not running
```

Based on offline comment from Guohan we have decided to pull in the changes done in (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/1429) to here and just have one single PR instead of 2 separate PRs.  Another reason is that the sonic-swss repo was not the right place for this new bgpmon daemon code to reside with.  Its functionality make more sense to be under "sonic-bgpcfgd".
@gechiang Could you add some unit test or vs test?

comments.body: What are the assumptions when you calculate PG headroom values?

I don't understand why 3800 has two PG profiles: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/device/mellanox/x86_64-mlnx_msn3800-r0/ACS-MSN3800/pg_profile_lookup.ini and https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/device/mellanox/x86_64-mlnx_msn3800-r0/Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8/pg_profile_lookup.ini.

> I don't understand why 3800 has two PG profiles: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/device/mellanox/x86_64-mlnx_msn3800-r0/ACS-MSN3800/pg_profile_lookup.ini and https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/device/mellanox/x86_64-mlnx_msn3800-r0/Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8/pg_profile_lookup.ini.

Hi @baiwei0427 
The one in `ACS-MSN3800` is the one calculated with the default parameters.
The one in `Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8` is the one calculated with the parameters you designated.

> they will be rounded up.

Do you mean they will be rounded up by SDK automatically?
I did calculations for all the cases and it seems to me that all the values are correct.

@vdahiya12: The PR builds are now failing because the sonic-config-engine unit tests do not run on any platform, therefore `sonic-py-common.get_platform()` returns None. Any unit test which calls `get_platform()` or another sonic-py-common function which calls `get_platform()` (e.g., `get_paths_to_platform_and_hwsku_dirs()` or `get_port_config_file_name()`) should mock those function(s), as they are part of a separate package, it is not testing them directly. Can you please add the appropriate mocks to the sonic-config-engine tests in the PR to allow the unit tests to pass?

reviews.body: As discussed, please also remove the `get_port_config_file_name()` function from portconfig.py as you had done in https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5253, and close that PR as it will be redundant to this one.

comments.body: @noaOrMlnx, can you please check with latest master. There was an issue where has_timer was passed in as a string and so it was evaluating to `True` all the time. That issues was fixed via [PR:5248](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5248)

@tahmed-dev I checked an image with the merged PR. 
The problem is caused when calling `update_feature_state` function, and trying to receive the has_timer field, even though there is no such field. 
`update_feature_state(feature_name, state, feature_table[feature_name]['has_timer'])` -> this call makes the feature initialization to fail if the feature doesn't have the field. 
This PRs purpose is to prevent the failure.

> @tahmed-dev I checked an image with the merged PR.
> The problem is caused when calling `update_feature_state` function, and trying to receive the has_timer field, even though there is no such field.
> `update_feature_state(feature_name, state, feature_table[feature_name]['has_timer'])` -> this call makes the feature initialization to fail if the feature doesn't have the field.
> This PRs purpose is to prevent the failure.

@noaOrMlnx what is the exact scenario where this new field `has_timer` would go missing? The reason is I see all feature have their `has_timer` fields populated in [init_cfg.json.j:21](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/files/build_templates/init_cfg.json.j2#L21). So, it is not clear to me which scenario requires this change.

> @noaOrMlnx what is the exact scenario where this new field has_timer would go missing? The reason is I see all feature have their has_timer fields populated in init_cfg.json.j:21. So, it is not clear to me which scenario requires this change.

@tahmed-dev This change is required for external features we have. Instead of changing the feature structure, this change will prevent the system to crush if the external feature doesn't have this field.

> ebtables service is only "After=local-fs.target", but not after rc.local. Will there be race condition?

No, as it is converting configuration file to atomic config, and at that time manually rules cannot be added to ebtables

reviews.body: lgtm..
@yxieca , can you review?
ebtables service is only "After=local-fs.target", but not after rc.local. Will there be race condition?

@lguohan: Thanks. I was unaware that we backported it.

@rlhui: In that case, we should probably try to cherry-pick this to 201911.

comments.body:
FYI, the check builds are failing because the unit test for this file expects an `interfaces` key to be present: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/sonic-device-data/tests/platform_json_checker#L47

So either you need to add an `interfaces` key with no values and a `TODO` comment, or adjust the test to gracefully handle the case where the `interfaces` key is not present (maybe print a warning and continue?). Also, once we solidify the format of this data, you need to add unit tests to also test these new platform hardware entries.

> FYI, the check builds are failing because the unit test for this file expects an `interfaces` key to be present: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/sonic-device-data/tests/platform_json_checker#L47
> 
> So either you need to add an `interfaces` key with no values and a `TODO` comment, or adjust the test to gracefully handle the case where the `interfaces` key is not present (maybe print a warning and continue?). Also, once we solidify the format of this data, you need to add unit tests to also test these new platform hardware entries.

Thanks, I added interfaces key with a comment. 
For the tests enhancement, I will keep a TODO item in my list.

> The platform.json file should reside under the platform directory, not the hardware SKU directory. In this case, it should be x86_64-mlnx_msn2700-r0//platform.json.

moved to suggested directory
@zhenggen-xu, @praveen-li, @samaity: Please take a look and let us know if you think extending the platform.json file like this aligns with your original design/intentions.

platform.json was initially not considered the information in this PR, but it was extendable since the ports related information was wrapped into "interfaces" section.  The issue I can see is,  we made the the logic in portconfig.py backwards compatible with port_config.ini, where we used the existence of platform.json as one of the critical to use the information in platform.json or port_config.ini.  We might want to use different file name here if we would like to onboard these two features separately.  Or we have to make changes in portconfig.py where we use "interfaces" empty as the indication of that info is not available in platform.json and still use port_config.ini.

@zhenggen-xu:

Thanks for the heads-up!

> Or we have to make changes in portconfig.py where we use "interfaces" empty as the indication of that info is not available in platform.json and still use port_config.ini.

I think this approach will work. I like the idea of keeping all fixed information about the platform in one file. We can modify the check in portconfig.py to do the following:

 If platform.json doesn't exist OR 'interfaces' not in platform.json OR the length of 'interfaces' == 0, then fall back to port_config.ini. How does that sound?

> @zhenggen-xu:
> 
> Thanks for the heads-up!
> 
> > Or we have to make changes in portconfig.py where we use "interfaces" empty as the indication of that info is not available in platform.json and still use port_config.ini.
> 
> I think this approach will work. I like the idea of keeping all fixed information about the platform in one file. We can modify the check in portconfig.py to do the following:
> 
> If platform.json doesn't exist OR 'interfaces' not in platform.json OR the length of 'interfaces' == 0, then fall back to port_config.ini. How does that sound?

sounds good to me.

@keboliu, @stephenxs, @Junchao-Mellanox, @stepanblyschak, @liat-grozovik: Please review this PR and provide feedback. The main idea here is to include static facts about the platform hardware that will be fixed among all devices of that platform in a new file, `platform.json`. This data is currently planned to be used in the platform API tests in sonic-mgmt as a "gold standard" reference with which to compare values retrieved from the API against to ensure correct functionality.

This file will also be used to hold dynamic port breakout information for all ports, and will eventually supplant port_config.ini. We may also find other uses for the file in the future. We decided to begin with the MSN2700 as the platform API implementations are currently the most mature.
@keboliu, @stephenxs, @Junchao-Mellanox: Please take another look and also review the threshold values, and make sure everything looks correct, and let us know if anything is missing.

Looks good to me.

@keboliu: Can you please review again?
@jleveque , can you approve it and merge it?

reviews.body: The platform.json file should reside under the platform directory, not the hardware SKU directory. In this case, it should be x86_64-mlnx_msn2700-r0//platform.json.
as comments

comments.body:
@yozhao101 @jleveque 

While looking into fix for Issue#https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/5292 I came across this PR.  I am wondering it will be easier we can use 'group' concept of monit.  We can control monitor/unmonitor of this group from hostcfgd same as how we start/unmask and stop/mask the service. I verified locally and looks good.

Updated Telemtry monit file with group

check process telemetry matching "/usr/sbin/telemetry"
    if does not exist for 5 times within 5 cycles then alert
    group telemetry.service

check process dialout_client matching "/usr/sbin/dialout_client_cli"
    if does not exist for 5 times within 5 cycles then alert
    group telemetry.service

Now when Feature is disabled we can execute sudo monit -g telemetry.service unmonitor from hostcfgd.
And when Feature is enabled we can execute sudo monit -g telemetry.service monitor from hostcfgd.

Any concern in this approach ?

@abdosi: Thank you for this suggestion. I think it is a feasable solution. The only concern I have is we would then spread the need for knowledge of Monit to other components (in this case, hostcfgd). I would prefer to encapsulate and abstract this knowledge as much as possible, but I wouldn't say it's a dealbreaker.

I think we can go ahead with this PR for the time being, and @yozhao101 can investigate the 'group' approach that you propose as a future cleanup/enhancement.

> @abdosi: Thank you for this suggestion. I think it is a feasable solution. The only concern I have is we would then spread the need for knowledge of Monit to other components (in this case, hostcfgd). I would prefer to encapsulate and abstract this knowledge as much as possible, but I wouldn't say it's a dealbreaker.
> 
> I think we can go ahead with this PR for the time being, and @yozhao101 can investigate the 'group' approach that you propose as a future cleanup/enhancement.

@jleveque Thanks. I felt since hostcfgd already has awareness with Feature Table and Services Enable/Disable monit going there makes it more logical.

> @abdosi: Thank you for this suggestion. I think it is a feasable solution. The only concern I have is we would then spread the need for knowledge of Monit to other components (in this case, hostcfgd). I would prefer to encapsulate and abstract this knowledge as much as possible, but I wouldn't say it's a dealbreaker.
> 
> I think we can go ahead with this PR for the time being, and @yozhao101 can investigate the 'group' approach that you propose as a future cleanup/enhancement.

@jleveque Thanks so much for helping me answering this question. I will investigate the `group` approach and give the feedback.

> Check builds are failing and there are conflicts. Please address.

Fixed.
@yozhao101: Will this PR cherry-pick cleanly to 201911, or will you need to open a separate PR?

> @yozhao101: Will this PR cherry-pick cleanly to 201911, or will you need to open a separate PR?

I will try cherry-pick this PR to 201911.

reviews.body: Check builds are failing and there are conflicts. Please address.

comments.body: @lguohan - could you please review and consider merge please, or do you have suggestion on who to request help from?
@jleveque, can you please review and sign off? thanks.
@sydlogan: Why do are you continually closing and reopening this PR?

@sydlogan: The Jenkins plugin we use for GitHub tests will retrigger tests when a special phrase is left in a comment on the PR.

To re-run a specific test, add a comment with the phrase, "Retest <test_name> please". To re-run ALL tests, use the word "this" in place of <test_name>.
@jleveque  -  thanks for the review so far, anything else?
Looks good to me. @sujinmkang: Any further comments/questions?

> Looks good to me. @sujinmkang: Any further comments/questions?

@jleveque No response to my pings for @sujinmkang to re-review.

@jleveque I noticed there is a "Conflicting files" message - guessing something came in that resulted in a merge issue. How is that generally handled in this project, will it be resolved when you merge it, or is there something I should be doing at this stage?
@slogan621: You must fix conflicts before the PR can be merged.

@jleveque okay. Do we need to do a new pull request? I have no idea what this conflict is, there is nothing to click on the tell. Would I find out maybe by trying to retest (using one of the methods you mentioned before when you asked why I was opening and closing the pull)?

@slogan621: You're modifying files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2, and it appears a commit merged which also modifies some of the same lines. You should be able to rebase your local branch on top of the latest HEAD of master, and git will stop rebasing at the point of conflict and allow you to resolve the conflict and continue with the rebase. There's plenty of documentation out on the web regarding resolving Git conflicts. A quick search turned this up: https://rollout.io/blog/resolve-github-merge-conflicts/

Also, there's no point in retesting anything at this moment, because the PR cannot be merged until the conflicts are fixed. All the tests will get er-run when you update the PR.

> @slogan621: You're modifying files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2, and it appears a commit merged which also modifies some of the same lines. You should be able to rebase your local branch on top of the latest HEAD of master, and git will stop rebasing at the point of conflict and allow you to resolve the conflict and continue with the rebase. There's plenty of documentation out on the web regarding resolving Git conflicts. A quick search turned this up: https://rollout.io/blog/resolve-github-merge-conflicts/
> 
> Also, there's no point in retesting anything at this moment, because the PR cannot be merged until the conflicts are fixed. All the tests will get er-run when you update the PR.

@jleveque thanks for the tip, that went smoothy, with tests passing, no merge conflicts at the moment.

Retest vsimage please

(out of disk failure in the test environment, to whom should such reports be sent, or are there notifications already in place?)

> (out of disk failure in the test environment, to whom should such reports be sent, or are there notifications already in place?)

@lguohan, @qiluo-msft: Can you please investigate?

vs is also failing (both for me and other contributors) in some bgp tests. I've seen this before over the past month, usually resubmitting will fix it but seems rather hard to get past in the past 24 hours.

vsimage tests keep failing after several hours with a timeout. I don't know what else to try but re-issue the test.

vs test fails seem to be really fundamental, in bgp:

self = <conftest.AsicDbValidator object at 0x7faef1f11f70>
dvs = <conftest.DockerVirtualSwitch object at 0x7faef1f650a0>

    def __init__(self, dvs):
        self.adb = swsscommon.DBConnector(1, dvs.redis_sock, 0)
    
        # get default dot1q vlan id
        atbl = swsscommon.Table(self.adb, "ASIC_STATE:SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_VLAN")
    
        keys = atbl.getKeys()
>       assert len(keys) == 1
E       assert 0 == 1
E         -0
E         +1

The tests can't seem to connect to a REDIS and read a fundamental table .  Not sure how that could have anything to do with gearbox.  Not sure that the test is executing validly either.

@sydlogan: It would appear that there are issues with the virtual switch caused by this PR. The vs test tests the vs docker image and the vsimage test tests the KVM image, and both seem to have issues. I suggest downloading one or both of the generated images from the Jenkins job and testing them locally.

> @sydlogan: It would appear that there are issues with the virtual switch caused by this PR. The vs test tests the vs docker image and the vsimage test tests the KVM image, and both seem to have issues. I suggest downloading one or both of the generated images from the Jenkins job and testing them locally.

Ultimately I need to identify what pull request accepted into any of the 5 projects (4 merged, 1 pending) broke this feature, at one point in the past few weeks.  Hoping it won't be trying to find a needle in the haystack :-|

What can you share with me on how to exactly replicate running the tests done at gate?
In order for the changes to supervisord to work, will need to first merge https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/1376. I've also got some minor changes to supervisord.conf I am testing as well.

I think the naming is correct here. PAI is the name of the .so that is bound to gearbox phy when we implement physical switch e.g. Celestica Silverstone DP , so this name is correct.  gbsyncd does not use SAI. PAI is roughly the same level of abstraction above hardware.

Some explanation of 6eaf960:

When looking at the change, it might be hard to see what was done just by looking at context diffs, but essentially this is what was done:

syncd_common.sh now has 99% of what was in syncd.sh and gbsyncd.

I found that in, say, the start entry point, syncd_common.sh was doing platform specific things that made no sense to do for phy/gb. This was also the case for the other entry points. These had to be pulled out and coupled with syncd,sh, decoupled from gbsyncd.sh.

So, I replaced that syncd-specific code with what effectively is a callback to the main script (e.g., syncd.sh). It's kind of like a callback, or maybe a perverse implementation of the pimpl pattern in the classic design patterns book (GOF). In gbsyncd, these callbacks became no-ops -- empty bash functions. In syncd, they implement that which only should be done for syncd, and are called at the very same point they were executed in the original script.
